How am I going to slow down?  I kept trying to apply the brakes to try to get it to stop, but it wasn't working.

I didn't want my car to spin, and it was on ice.  I didn't know which direction my car was going to spin, so I kind of cut the wheel back, and then every time a car would hit me, my car would bounce back, and because of the angle of my -- the way I had turned my wheel all the way over, my car was just -- every time it bounced back, it would just push further into the middle. Because I put my wheel to the right.  I started off over to the left, and then I didn't want my car to go into a spin, so I cut my wheel, but there was really nowhere to go at that point because there was a car in front of me, which, you know, I couldn't stop the car.  I tried to stop the car by hitting the guardrail, but it did not work.  The cars were just kind of banging me from behind, and I was just kind of -- my car just started sliding back and forth, which ended up pushing me out to the middle.  That's all I know. You know, I didn't want anyone to get hurt. So, like, the car I impacted, they were stuck because they hit -- you know, there was no room for them to go through with that truck the way it was.

I'm, like, what about insurance and all this other stuff?  Then I was, like, you know, when I got home, I had more questions.  I'm, like, what the heck, you know.  Is anybody going to cover everything because I was feeling like a victim as well.  We were all victims that day on the road. And I got home, and I'm, like, what the heck? You know, so I called the state and to be, like, hey, is the state going to do anything to cover all this damage because the roads were icy, and then I really didn't get anywhere with that because they said it was a no-fault accident.

I went on the ambulance with my mom, and then my kids went on a bus.  They were separated from me, and they were driven to the same hospital.

text: I'm sorry.  What kind of car was that person driving?

Like, I didn't want to take the middle because of the fact that that truck was right there, and I didn't want -- like I said, I was so worried about maybe decapitating -- you know, driving under the truck because I couldn't stop.  So I just didn't know which route was the best way to take.  I just knew that the guardrail was there, and then maybe I could slow my car down if I maybe tried to go up against it.  I didn't know how to slow my car down besides applying brakes, which there was no friction on the ground.  So I don't know.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you observe any vehicles that were further down the road from the truck that you've been describing?

text: No, because the truck just blocked everything.  The truck literally took up all the road even the end two rows.  There was, like, a car that was kind of smushed in between.  Like, the one that I ended up impacting, it was already smushed up because it couldn't go past that one car and the truck.  I don't know if the truck actually hit that one car or if those two cars were at the same time trying to stop and impacted there together.  I don't know how that happened.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And then from where you were --
speaker: MR. LOVEALL

text: But I don't think there was --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So from where you were, did you see other cars colliding?
speaker: MR. LOVEALL

text: I couldn't see any other cars colliding. All the cars were colliding into me because they kept coming over the hill and then hitting me.  The only thing I could see was that one tractor-trailer truck. There was another family actually, but they were all the way over to the -- they took the right side, or at least I kept to the inside.  But they were already there as well before -- you know, I didn't see anything that had happened with them.  I just know when I was facing at the diagonal, that, you know, I knew that there was another family off to the right. I didn't see them hit or anything.  I don't know what was going on with them.  I was just, you know, in a state of shock.  It was pretty traumatic. So I didn't see anybody impacting.  It was just my car.  I saw the cars up ahead come to a stop.  I saw brake lights, but after I saw the brake lights on the truck, then I was just in a panic mode because I kept trying to brake and I couldn't brake no matter where I was braking, and that's when I tried to go over to the side.  And so everything else -- there were just cars that came up over that hill.  They just kept colliding into -- you know, into the next car, which was me, because I think they all had the same idea, and they -- I just kept getting rammed, like, three more times from behind. And then the last time I thought I was going to get hit again, another truck had jackknifed at the top of that hill.  So then there was probably cars on the other side of that that didn't know what was going on, and they were just hitting that truck, and then people could see at that point.  So I think that's where it kind of came to an end.  It was a backup of traffic.

So I was trying to keep my car straight, but maybe just to slow it down or stop it by just going against the rail, and then I found out that it really wasn't doing anything.  I cut my wheel back quickly, and then that's when I ran out of space because there was nowhere for me to go.

And then my car slid back again, and as it kept moving, it being pushed back on the ice, I was just kind of sliding back and forth on the ice, and so the third hit, that's when I got pushed all the way out to under the -- by the tractor-trailer kind of underneath their gas tank right there. And then that was the last hit that I received, like I said, thankfully.  Then that's when, I guess, the truck at the top of the hill must have jackknifed because no more cars were coming down, and then there was some more crashes that followed that I heard, but that was just the cars, you know, from that truck jackknifing, and then the cars there just, you know, kind of last minute probably not expecting a truck to just jackknife on an interstate.  So I don't know.  I don't know what happened behind me.  I just know -- all I know is that three more cars had hit me.  Not three more cars but -- you know, because we're kind of back to back.  Like, I guess the car behind that car was hitting the car in back of me.  It was just kind of -- it was rough.  I don't know.  It was pretty traumatic. text: Miss Witham, you're being recorded, every conversation you're having with your daughter right here.  I prefer if you just answer the questions.
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: I was just trying to be helpful by looking at the pictures.  I apologize. Continue.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So I think the question was how many pictures do you have of the accident?
speaker: MR. LOVEALL

text: Eleven.  I guess possibly there's 11.  I'm just counting ones that are on my daughter's phone.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you also take photos there?
speaker: MR. LOVEALL

text: Who, me?  No.  I was -- no.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: The next question is --
speaker: MR. LOVEALL

text: That was not on my agenda.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Understood.  When you were driving up the hill that we talked about, what was your speed?
speaker: MR. LOVEALL

text: I was just going normal speed.  Whatever the speed limit was.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Not less than the speed limit?
speaker: MR. LOVEALL

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was it raining when you were driving up the hill?  Or rather what was the weather like --
speaker: MR. LOVEALL

text: I don't think it was raining.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What was the weather like when you were driving up the hill?
speaker: MR. LOVEALL

text: It just seemed like normal weather.  It didn't seem like anything out of the ordinary.  I don't recall.  I mean, I don't recall that it was raining at all.  It was just regular weather.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: That's all the questions I have.  I think some of the lawyers might have other questions, but thank you.
speaker: MR. LOVEALL

text: Good afternoon, Miss Witham.
speaker: MS. THEBAUD

text: Good afternoon.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: This is Attorney Darlene Thebaud.  Can you hear me?
speaker: MS. THEBAUD

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I represent the defendants Harvey Radey and Stonewall Kitchen.  My client was driving the Penske tractor-trailer.  I'm just going to ask you a few follow-up questions.
speaker: MS. THEBAUD

text: (Phone was disconnected)
(A brief break was taken)
Jane, it's Darlene Thebaud.  Can you hear me?
speaker: MS. THEBAUD

text: Yes, much clearer.  Thank you.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I represent the defendants Harry Radey and Stonewall Kitchen, the tractor-trailer that was involved in the accident.  I just have a few follow-up questions for you.
speaker: MS. THEBAUD

text: Sure.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And I'm just going to ask that you listen to the question and just try to answer the question that I'm asking.
speaker: MS. THEBAUD

text: Okay.  Yes, ma'am.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So you testified earlier that when you first saw the tractor-trailer, it was at a stop, correct?
speaker: MS. THEBAUD

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you had testified --
speaker: MS. THEBAUD

text: And --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Sorry.  I'm going to ask the next question.  You had testified that you believe that it was jackknifing, but you didn't actually see it jackknifing, correct?
speaker: MS. THEBAUD

text: That's correct.  I didn't see how it made it to the position that it was at.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Thank you.  Did you ever have any conversations with the driver of that tractor-trailer?
speaker: MS. THEBAUD

text: No.  No, ma'am.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you have any conversations with anyone at the scene that had a mustache?
speaker: MS. THEBAUD

text: Not to my knowledge.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you ever see the vehicle that the plaintiff, Miss Rhodes, was driving, a Chrysler, a black Chrysler?  Did you ever see that vehicle on the road at the time of your accident?
speaker: MS. THEBAUD

text: I really wasn't making out what types of vehicles were around me at the time.  It was just really bad.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And I believe you testified --
speaker: MS. THEBAUD

text: I don't know where her vehicle was at in the accident either.  I don't know where anybody's vehicle was at.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did you ever get anyone's names at the scene that you spoke with?
speaker: MS. THEBAUD

text: No.  I really wasn't talking to a lot of people.  The only one I really spoke with was the police officer who informed me that we were going to be transferred over to the hospital.  My mom was kind of stuck in the car, so we were kind of trapped in there.  I wasn't leaving my mom.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Were you or anyone in your vehicle injured?
speaker: MS. THEBAUD

text: Yes.  I had fractured my hand.  My daughter had a concussion, and my son had something wrong with his ear at the time of the incident.  And my mom, I think she had -- I'm trying to think of the word.  I can't think of the name of what my mom had. Like, whiplash maybe.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did any of you make claims for injury as a result of the accident?
speaker: MS. THEBAUD

text: Like, the insurance company had -- yes, with the insurance company.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Objection.
speaker: MR. LENTINI

text: With my brother's insurance company, they had covered what they could of the medical bills.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you were driving your brother's car, correct?
speaker: MS. THEBAUD

text: I was, yes.  My car -- I had problems with my car up there, and I had to get back to go to work, and so he had just let me borrow his car.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I'm sorry.  What did you say at the end there?
speaker: MS. THEBAUD

text: I had to get back to work.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What kind of car were you driving?
speaker: MS. THEBAUD

text: Again, I don't know the make and model. It was just a blue four-door car.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did you actually receive a settlement payment for your injuries?
speaker: MS. THEBAUD

text: I think they just -- no.  They covered -- they just gave me a quote that they could cover, I believe, the medical expenses, and then whatever went over those medical expenses, I had to pay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: You had to pay after the medical expenses were covered?
speaker: MS. THEBAUD

text: Whatever they didn't cover.  I think there's, like, a certain amount up to.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was that amount $8,000?
speaker: MS. THEBAUD

text: I really don't remember.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you recall if you received any checks from any insurance companies other than your brother's?
speaker: MS. THEBAUD

text: Objection.
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: I don't think that I received any checks. I believe they went straight to the hospital.  I didn't receive any checks from anybody.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And you had testified that you slid into a car in front you; is that correct?
speaker: MS. THEBAUD

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What kind of car was that?
speaker: MS. THEBAUD

text: If I'm not mistaken, it was the one that was in front of me, which was the one -- the gray charcoal car.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Was it a car or an SUV?
speaker: MS. THEBAUD

text: I think it was a car.  It was a -- I believe it was -- I'm looking at the pictures.  If I had to say, it would be the gray charcoal car, which was up against the median.  I got rammed into that car, I think, a couple of times, and I kept sliding back, and then my car ended up into the middle.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So after you slid into the gray charcoal car, another car pushed you into the middle?
speaker: MS. THEBAUD

text: Had hit me, and then I hit that car again, and then I came out.  I think I hit that car one more time, and then my car finally cleared that car, and that's how I ended up where I was.  I don't know who was in that car in front of me, but my car was pushed into it a couple of times.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you ultimately ended up right next to the tractor-trailer's gas tank, but not touching it?
speaker: MS. THEBAUD

text: Yeah.  Yes.  I was, like, right there.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And do you think that there was anything you could have done to avoid this accident?
speaker: MS. THEBAUD

text: Objection.
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: No, ma'am.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Thank you.  That's all I have.  Thank you.
speaker: MS. THEBAUD

text: Jane, there's two other lawyers.  They may have a few follow-up questions as well.
speaker: MR. LENTINI

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Miss Witham, my name is Bridget Lopez.  I represent Melissa Pomeroy, who's another defendant being sued in this case.
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you recognize the name Melissa Pomeroy?
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: I do not.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And as I understand it, you didn't take down any names of other people at the scene; is that right?
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: That is correct.  I was concerned about my family.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: We attempted to have your attorney e-mail or -- I'm sorry -- text over just one photograph listed as Exhibit 1.  Do you have that on your cell phone?  Did that text come through?
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: I can check it, if you don't mind?  Give me a moment.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Please.
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: It was a text?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: It was just an MMS text, Jane.  It shows a scene that Miss Rhodes's counsel brought, and it has a bunch of numbers on the car.
speaker: MR. LENTINI

text: Hold on.  Let me just see.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: See if you got a recent text from me.
speaker: MR. LENTINI

text: Oh, I see some photos.  Hold on.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is it a picture with a bunch of numbers on it?
speaker: MR. LENTINI

text: Yeah.  I see one photo.  You want me to visually -- let me try to make it bigger. Is there a question in regards to that one photo?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: There will be.
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: Okay.  I see the photo.  I see my car, the car I was driving in front of the truck.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Miss Witham, hold on just one second.  I want to make sure you had an opportunity to look at that photograph.  Have you had that opportunity?
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: Let me get a good look at it.  Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: (Exhibit No. 1, Two Pages of Photocopied Photographs, marked for identification)

Okay.  I'm going to ask you a question about that photograph that was just texted over.  The photograph, for the record, has been marked as Exhibit 1, page 1 of 2.  Now, in that photograph, do you see the accident location?
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: I do.  I'm trying to see what angle it was taken at, but I see vehicles on the other side of the median.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Yes.  Great.  Wait for my question.  And do you see in that photograph, what we've marked as Exhibit 1, the first page of Exhibit 1, seven different numbers labeled over the cars in that photograph?  Do you see that?
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: I'm going to look right now.  I have to take my ear away from the phone.  Yes, I see the numbers.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Great.  Do you see the car you were operating that day numbered in that photograph?
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: Yes.  You want the number?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Please.
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: Let me check.  That would be number 4.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Great.  I think we're all on the same page then.  There's one other vehicle in that photograph I wanted you to look at.  The one that's listed as number 2 appears to be a gray charcoal car.  Is that the gray charcoal car that you were speaking about earlier in your deposition testimony?
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: Please give me one second.  Let me look. I guess that would be number 2.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Great.  So we're on the same page.  When you were talking about a gray charcoal car, are we all in agreement that was number 2 is what we see in that photograph?
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: Hold on.  Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Great.  And there's one other vehicle in that photograph.  There's a big, white tractor-trailer marked as number 3.  Do you see that?
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And that's the tractor-trailer that you came to a rest at?
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And it's hard to tell from the angle in this photograph, but is it your testimony that your vehicle never touched that truck at all -- that tractor-trailer at all?
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: That is correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: It was, like, almost against it, but it didn't touch the truck at all.  Because, like, in front of me was the gas tank.  I remember that pretty clearly, which kind of freaked me out.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When you said it was against it, was there actual physical contact between your car and that tractor-trailer?
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: No.  Other than, like, if a car came and whacked me, I would have been in his gas tank, and there would have been another problem.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Hang on with me here.  I just want to make sure that when you were pushed towards that tractor-trailer, you never actually touched it?
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: That is correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So then fair to say that that tractor-trailer never moved once you came to your final resting place; is that fair?
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: Yes.  That truck was pretty stationary where it was.  I don't think any -- yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did you strike any cars as you headed from your lane over towards the left median?
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: Are you saying going from, like, the top of the hill going down when I was going over to the median?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Yes.
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: I had pretty free rein.  That's why I kept just trying to stop my car, and I just couldn't stop my car.  So I went all the way over and tried to stop it with that --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Great.
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: -- but, again, there was ice on the ground.  I didn't hit no cars, if that was your question.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Thank you.  It was.  So the first thing that you came up against was that left median?
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: Say it again.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: The first thing -- I think you said you bumped into something.  The first thing you bumped into was that left median strip?
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: Yeah, that's the only thing.  That's the only thing I made contact with when I first got there.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When you came up over the incline, I take it it started to descend?  The road started to descend?
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: I don't understand that question.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Sure.  When there's an incline, there's a decline.  So when you came up the --
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: There was a decline.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And the accident that you've described, that occurred on the declined portion of this roadway?
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: Uh-huh.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Yes?
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When you first got over to the crest of the incline, I know you mentioned you saw some brake lights ahead of you?
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: When I got to the top of the hill, that's when I saw brake lights.  That's when I applied my brakes and realized I didn't have any.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And was it you just saw brake lights from the car ahead of you in your lane, or did you see multiple brake lights ahead of you?
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: Yes.  All I remember was just seeing brake lights, and that's obviously brakes.  It was pretty normal at that point, and then I realized when my car started skidding, you know -- I don't know.  I was just taking it all in at once.  Everything was just happening so fast.  So everything was, like, in seconds.  It's not, like, there was a moment and then there's another moment.  No.  Everything is, like, in seconds.  I applied my brakes at the same time I was viewing -- because I saw brakes, and at the same time I was applying my brakes, my car was skidding.  I was seeing the truck across the road, and then I was moving over.  So it wasn't like there was pauses in between.  That's not the case.  Everything was just automatic. So I was multitasking.  The first thing I saw was brake lights.  So I applied my brakes.  At the same time I was viewing the rest of the area, and I saw the truck all the way across, and that's when I started freaking out and trying to figure out where I was going to go in all of this.  There was no place for me to go.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Hold up a second.  It would be really helpful if you just answered my question.
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: I apologize.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: It happens all the time.  It's just more difficult on the phone. I guess my point is, I want to know, did you -- you saw brake lights which caused you to apply your brakes, right?
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: Right.  Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When was the first -- did you ever actually notice why the car was starting to brake? For example, did you notice any accident ahead of you?
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: When I came up over the hill, I just saw brake lights.  I applied my brakes, and that's when I noticed that there was an accident sitting before me. I noticed it all -- it was all taken in when I saw the brake lights.  I automatically applied my brakes, and then I obviously had a visual of the truck all the way across the interstate.  Everything just happened instantly.  It was all instant.  Brake lights, applied brakes, saw everything laid out in front of me, and my next step was where am I going to go.  If my brakes aren't working at the same time, where am I going to go to try and not hurt people in my car.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I get that.  Is it fair to say you had no recognition that an accident had happened ahead of you until the point that you got to the incline?
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So is it fair to say that the incline impeded your view of what was going on ahead?
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: The 11 photographs that you've reviewed that your daughter took at the accident scene --
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: Uh-huh.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: -- I understand that you're going to forward those to your attorney, right?
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: Yes, I can do so.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Great.  Those 11 photographs that you've testified to, are they a fair and accurate representation of what the accident scene looked like immediately following the accident?
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: The one that you had showed me or the other ones?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: The other ones that your daughter took.  I just want to know -- to be able to use these at trial, I have to know if they show what they're supposed to show or show something relevant.  So my question to you is these 11 photographs that we're going to get, are they fair and accurate representations of what that accident scene looked like while you were still on scene?
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: Again, they were pictures taken by my daughter when she was -- when she had gotten out of the car with the policeman to escort her or whatever. So I really can't answer that question.  I mean, they were pictures of the accident, you know.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Well, ma'am, you reviewed the photographs as we were taking this deposition?
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: I did.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And as you looked at those photographs, did they appear to be good pictures of what was shown at the accident scene?
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: Yes.  I really don't know what you're looking for when you're asking me these questions, so -- they are of the accident that had taken place.  So when you say "good," I don't know --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Well, I just want to make sure they represent the accident scene.  That's all.
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: They do.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I don't have any further questions.  Thank you, ma'am.  There's one other attorney who may ask you questions.
speaker: MS. LOPEZ

text: Good afternoon.  My name is Jim McLaughlin, and I represent another driver, Jessica Quist.  I do not have any questions for you.
speaker: MR. MCLAUGHLIN

text: Thank you.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I have one last question.
speaker: MR. LOVEALL

text: At any point after the accident, did you go in front of the truck further down the road from where your car was?
speaker: MR. LOVEALL

text: I have seen pictures afterwards, but during the accident, again, the only person I spoke with, I believe, from my recollection and my memory, was the police officer who told me that they were going to help my family out and escort us off out of our vehicle into another vehicle, and they got us off the road.  So I wasn't trying to walk around.  I wasn't trying to see anything.  I was pretty much in shock mode.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So just to be clear, so you didn't actually go in front of the truck further down the road from where you were; is that right?
speaker: MR. LOVEALL

text: I didn't have any means of making it down that way nor did I have -- yes.  Correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Thank you so much for your time today.  Thank you.
speaker: MR. LOVEALL

text: Jane, it's Dave.  You're all set.  Thank you very much.  I'll talk to you early next week.
speaker: MR. LENTINI
